newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.

text.p: Aggressive offshore and local institutional buying pummelled bond yields to fresh 16-month lows on Thursday, bringing the market's gains to almost 80 basis points in the last two weeks.
At 1400 GMT, the benchmark R150 was pegged at a 14.095 percent yield -- down 14 points from Wednesday's 14.245 percent finish and compared with 14.88 percent on June 18.
"There has been huge, huge demand across the board, the majority of it starting again in the mediums similar to yesterday," a trader said.
On Wednesday, the TK06, TK16 and E169 all rallied as players began discounting an interest rate cut, which economists expect in the second half of this year.
Dealers said the longer-end of the curve also attracted demand. "The R153s and R184s have been the stars," a trader said.
The yield on the R184 and R153 were both last quoted at 14.12 percent from 14.295 percent and 14.265 percent respectively on Tuesday.
"The R153 is now trading one or two points to the 150s and that hasn't happened for a long time," a trader said.
Traders said, however, that it was unclear what had sparked the demand.

One cited stronger U.S. Treasuries, which were given a fresh fillip in early New York trade by bullish employment data in the wake of the Federal Reserve's decision not to hike U.S. interest rates late on Wednesday.
Another trader said there had been talk in the market of a zero-coupon eurorand issue in the offing, as well as talk of an asset swap which had left a player short of the long end.

The assault that ensued hurled the R150 through technical resistance at 14.20 down to the 14.10 percent level where dealers said the market ran into sizeable profit-taking by a London-based institution.
Fears that the market was technically overbought and due for a retracement were generally shrugged off and dealers said they expected fresh gains again on Friday.
On the currency market, the rand benefited from mainly offshore and exporter dollar sales which dealers said outweighed small amounts of importer demand.
In late trade, it was quoted at 4.5245/5265 against the dollar from 4.5295/5325 overnight.
"We've seen flows from exporters and quite a bit from offshore," a trader said. "There has not been much demand."
Dealers said the rand's efforts to push below the 4.52 level had been stymied by both the local demand and the fact that the dollar had posted a fresh 40-month high against the Deutschmark.

Against the crosses, the rand slumped to a fresh five month low against sterling as cable rallied to its strongest level since January in the wake of the British Labour government's budget presented late on Wednesday.
The rand was last trading at 7.6112/6208 against sterling from 7.4776/4871 late on Wednesday.
Against the mark and yen, the rand was last at 0.3864/3868 from 0.3859/3864 overnight and at 25.0768/1155 yen from 25.2372/2759 yen.

On the money market, three-month NCDs were quoted at between 14.75 and 14.80 percent offered, while the 90-day BA rate was slightly lower at between 15.15 and 15.35 percent from 15.20 to 15.35 percent.
The Reserve Bank quoted the money market shortage lower at 5.379 billion rand on Wednesday from 5.901 billion rand on Tuesday.
Bond Exchange figures showed foreigners were net buyers 732.6 million rand's worth of South African bonds on Wednesday after buying 109.6 million rand's worth on Tuesday.
Nominal cumulative volumes on the bond market on Wednesday were 10.05 billion rand from 9.9 billion rand on Tuesday.
-- Paul Richardson, Johannesburg newsroom +27 11 482 1003
